'''Albert Ross Eckler, Jr.''' (born August 29, 1927) is a [[logologist]] and [[statistician]], and author, the son of statistician [[A. Ross Eckler]]. He received a B.A. from [[Swarthmore College]] and a Ph.D. in mathematics from [[Princeton University]].

==Biography ==
While at [[Bell Labs]], Eckler co-authored ''Mathematical Models of Target Coverage and Missile Allocation'' with [[Stefan A. Burr]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Eckler, Jr.|first=Albert Ross|author2=Burr, Stefan|title=Mathematical models of target coverage and missile allocation|publisher=[[Military Operations Research Society]], Alexandria, Va.|year=1972|edition=1st|asin=B0006W2E2O |oclc=1183447}}</ref>

Eckler is the former publisher and editor of ''[[Word Ways: The Journal of Recreational Linguistics]]''. He wrote a book on [[logology]] titled Making the Alphabet Dance.

He is also the author of ''The National Puzzlers' League, The First 115 Years,'' a history of the [[National Puzzlers' League]] (NPL).<ref>{{cite book|last=Eckler, Jr.|first=Albert Ross|title=The National Puzzlers' League, The First 115 Years|publisher=National Puzzlers' League, New York|year=1998|edition=1st|asin=B001B3MEEU |oclc=55705246}}</ref> He and his wife Faith have been married for more than 50 years,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wordways.com/meetEcklers.htm|title=Meet the Ecklers|last=Farrell|first=Jeremiah|publisher=http://wordways.com|accessdate=8 March 2010}}</ref> and are former NPL editors under the collective [[nom de plume]] "Faro" (with variant forms "FAro" for Faith and "faRO" for Ross).<ref>[http://puzzlers.org/guide/index.php?expand=refs Reference Books and Periodicals For Puzzle Solvers and Composers], Merlin (updated by Saxifrage), National Puzzlers' League, accessed 2015-02-07; under periodicals this lists "Word Ways: The Journal of Recreational Linguistics, published quarterly by Faro (Faith and Ross Eckler)".</ref>

Eckler's hobbies are [[genealogy]] and [[supercentenarian]] research. Eckler has disproved exaggerated age claims such as those of [[Charlie Smith (centenarian)|Charlie Smith]] and [[George Fruits]] while authenticating others such as [[Delina Filkins]] (1815â€“1928).
